narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: 1) The readings were unnecessary and bear no relation to the lectures or homework assignments.2) The professor is admirable. He comes with a wealth of knowledge. The problem is that he was inefficient at structuring the actual coursework. The schedule was not adhered to. The deadlines were not adhered to. The instances where he was supposed to e-mail the students information was always significantly (and inconveniently) delayed. He seemed to structure the course a certain way because he thought he "had to" as opposed to fitting in organically with the material he was presenting.
This is the best agriculture class I have ever had. And we have a great teacher! Yale should hire prof. Gollin!
For future courses in this area, it would be much more helpful to have either an Economics PhD or someone with background in the subject area.
The first month was very slow and there was a lot of work towards the end.

For Agriculture and the Environment -- Professor Gollin is an _excellent_ teacher. He puts a great deal of effort into his lectures, and really cares whether students understand the material and have a good experience in the course. He stands out among professors at Yale for this.
Course structure was not organized well and ad-hoc.

I had high hopes for this class. While I found the subject matter very interesting, I think the pace was way too slow. We had some class sessions that were jam packed with interesting info, and others that were terribly boring, without much new material covered. I think that Doug is an excellent lecturer and teacher, but that he was too quick to indulge certain students' commentary. I would have liked the class to be structured more tightly, with a concrete schedule that we could stick to. This was lacking.

I audited the class, so I was not an active participant. I wish I could have attended more classes because my friends all seemed to enjoy the course, but I become overloaded with work for my other courses. Apologies! I wish this class was offered in the spring so that students could take econ their first semester and then take this after. That was why I audited the class--I didn't have the recommended preparation in econ.
The teacher was very flexible and open to suggestions.

Happening! F&ES has an important gap in its curriculum and this is agriculture and the environment. This class covered the economic side of it. I also think that the professor, not being an environmentalist, was able to give a very refreshing point of view in all issues within this topic and how non-environmentalist perceive them.

The instructor was intelligent and attentive to the various interests of the students in class. Flexibility on the topics addressed in assignments made the course a great way to explore individual interests related to agriculture.
Learn to think problem from different perspectives

The Professor. He has a deep knowledge in the subject area and made a special effort to help us thing about issues of agriculture from new angles. I especially appreciated that he was willing to challenge current paradigms in environmental thought such as about biofuels and local foods- I think that this class gave all of us both valuable information and new tools with which to process information.
The class was very relevant and used current data.

Agriculture&the Environment - The subject matter. This topic is one which is incomplete if looked at from any single angle, and we managed to cover the wide spectrum of essential issues in good depth.
Only agriculture class available at FES.
The dedication to agricultural economics.

It's the only course focused on the economics of agriculture, which is an area many students are looking to gain experience in. The lectures were interesting and covered a variety of important topics.
the instructor is very considerate!

The professor was extremely flexible in tailoring the course to fit the interests of the students. There was a perfect mix of economics and history/description of agricultural trends to keep the class interesting and relevant.
Professor is really nice!

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: completely disorganized. didn't follow syllabus. went WAY too slow. problem sets never discussed in class.
See above
Better time management during class, and better integration of quantitative and theoretical topics.
A more solid reliable schedule for assignments.Teaching at a slightly faster pace and using office hours for help as needed.
it would be better if we get the lecture ppt in advance
Organization.
The beginning. It was very slow. The problem sets very long. Too much in the second have, compared to almost no work at the beginning.

Agriculture and the Environment - The one thing that would be useful, the next time the course is taught, would be to have a better idea of which of the readings on the syllabus we'll need to get through for each class. I felt a little bit lost in the readings a couple of times, but in all fairness we were warned that this might happen, since it was the first run-through for the course.

Organization, solid class structure.Forming a group based on who you know in the class was not professional. TA or the professor should have given the topics or at least disclosed who's working on what topics so that team formation should be based on one's interest.
Structure, organization.

Since this was the first time this course was offered, there were some kinks to work out. The readings could have been better. I would have also preferred for the group project to have come earlier in the semester so it was not timed just before the final exam.
The course is designed for more discussion, however, the class scale is too big for that.
Pacing. We fell behind schedule with the course material, and towards the end we lost track of what we were supposed to learn. But luckily the final helped summarize the important concepts.
BETTER organization

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: TA helped with problem sets.

Mary Fischer was very available and helpful. In the instances where she was less than helpful, it was simply because the teacher hadn't provided her with the necessary information. Other than that, she was great and readily available.
The TA was available and helpful, but I did not seek much help from her during the course.

I received excellent assistance from the Professor on all projects. He was very accessible and is very good at framing research questions/ helping students to explore their academic interests in new ways.
Excellent. The professor was always available and helpful

Agriculture&Environment - The instructor was more easily accessible than most professors I've interacted with, and gave good, helpful insights. I didn't interact with the TA very much so I can't make an assessment.
The TA and instructor were very available, and their help was very useful.
Professor Gollin was always available to discuss topics out of class. He was very generous with his time and committed to the students. The TA was helpful as well.
the instructor is the most smart and considerate professor I have ever met! He could easily tell what is your question and respond it correspondingly.

Both the professor and the TA were readily available for help. The instructor was very encouraging and took the time to answer questions fully and provide help on the course material outside the classroom - a wonderful professor.
They are really helpful.
The TA wasn't very useful; responsive, yes, but not helpful at all.
very good

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This course should be properly titled "Agricultural Economics". I don't think a single person understood that this would be an economics course.

This fits both into the energy and development aspects of my program. Professor Gollin was great about letting my pursue my interests in bioenergy from the agriculture perspective. Also, this class exposes students to very interesting and relevant aspects of development economics and the role of agriculture in development. I think it is great that FES is offering more classes like this, and I hope they continue to do so.

For people who want to want to focus on policy analysis, i thought this was a very good course. Also, i thought that for people interested in doing work in developing countries like me, it is very relevant.

Agriculture and Environmen - This course is an important subject area for me, since I'm focusingon agriculture in my dissertation. I'm a first-year phd student coming from a pretty solid background in agricultural development issues, and this course was helpful in giving me a concrete framework to put some of my past learning into, and hopefully to carry forward as I do my own research.
I am focusing on agriculture, so it was nice to have a class dedicate to it.
Learning about the economics of agriculture and agricultural policies helps me understand the interplay between local land use, agriculture, and conservation better.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: This was the only agriculture course offered at F&ES, even though it was really an economics course in disguise.
I like the teaching passion of Douglas'
In order to study bioenergy from an agricultural economics perspective.

For my case, because i'm very interested in the impact of economic activities in the environment, and agriculture is a huge sector that has significant impact in developed and developing countries, i thought it was an extremely relevant course. Also, the course not only covered agriculture as an activity, but agricultural policies and the impacts that those have.
Agriculture&Environment - See above; was interested in topic area.
It is the only agriculture-related class at FES.
See above
I am interested in how environmental economics is applied in the real world, agriculture is one of filed I would like to see its application.
I was very interested in taking this course because of my background work in agriculture prior to coming to FES.
Interested in agri-economics.
I'm interested in agriculture and land use.
Learn more about ag and the environment.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: NO.
Despite the false expectations, the course was interesting and it increased my interest in environmental economics, in general.
Yes- surpassed in fact.
Yes. I learned a lot and enjoyed the class.
Agriculture and Environment - Yes!
Yes, somewhat.
No
Yes
over my expectation
Yes.
Yes, learned a lot of interesting topics, and went deep into some of them.
I wish we could have covered more topics in class. We spent quite some time on economic models, and I would have preferred a more interdisciplinary approach.
More economics han I expected.
yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: NO.
Yes
Yes, and I am willing to learn more details!
Yes
Agriculture and Environment - Yes, I did, and actually got more than I expected in terms of improving my understanding of the economic models that underpin resource management analyses.
Yes.
I got a lot out of it, but felt that it could have offered a lot more.
Yes
Yes.
Yes
I got something different from what I expected. I understand the economics much better now, but I'm not sure it was what I wanted.
Yes, eventually.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: waste of time.

The group work was unnecessary. Writing a group paper at the end of the semester, considering half the class was already out of town, proved to be difficult. The group paper should have taken place during midterms instead.
The time is a little bit short

Because group work requires a lot of coordination, it would have been better to have started earlier in the semester. The upside was that we were evaluated based on our individual contributions rather than the project as a whole, which I find preferable.

I had a very good group, so the usual disadvantages (e.g. unequal distribution of work, lack of organization, etc.) didn't come up. The advantage, in this case, was getting to learn a great deal more about a subject area that interested me than I would've learned had I undertaken the project on my own.
Difference in motivation toward this class was the most difficult part. No specific advantages.
The project was a little too loosely defined, so it wasn't the most rewarding project in the end. I did appreciate the practice in public speaking that it provided.

I enjoyed being able to take on a bigger subject than I would have been able to cover individually and get to know some of the other students in my class. The disadvantage of group work is that not everyone pulls their weight.

The group work was an effective way to examine an area of agriculture from a variety of angles and viewpoints. Other than the usual issues of time constraints that accompany group meetings, I found this project to be highly conducive to group work and that there were few disadvantages.
Advantage is to practice teamwork.Disadvantage is that the communication is not efficient enough.We need to practice more on teamwork skills.
Finding a group and formulating a coherent topic was hard.
I like working on my own better.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be clear - this is an economics course, not an ag course. If you've already taken an econ course, this may seem a bit repetitive. But, the teacher is incredibly smart and flexible, so you get out of it what you put in, basically.
Be prepared for the problem sets because they are long.

Go with the flow; ask questions; and make sure you get as much out of the problem-sets as possible. Also -- do the readings! Although this is a lecture-based course, one of the best parts of it is the professor's willingness to engage in discussion with students. You'll get a lot more out of it if you have your own questions and critiques of the models presented in the readings to bring up in class.
You should be aware that it is an economics class.
it is a discussion-focused class, be prepared to read before the class and take part in the discussion.
It is very useful to use the short papers to explore personal topics of interest related to the course.
Do more readings and participate more into the course.
be prepared for economics.
